facts.text: Respondent committed to Court of Sessions to stand trial under s. 493, or in the alternative under s. 495, of the Indian Penal Code, on charge that he had by deceit caused appellant, who was not lawfully married to him, to believe she was married, and in that belief had sexual intercourse with her; alternatively, married appellant after concealing fact that he was already married.
Prosecution launched by petition of complaint filed by appellant before Magistrate.
Respondent tried by Additional Sessions Judge, Gurdaspur, who by judgment dated December 31, 1959, acquitted him on ground that prosecution failed to prove marriage between complainant and accused.
Appellant filed application on April 22, 1960 for special leave to appeal from order of acquittal under s. 417(3) CrPC, later than 60 days from acquittal.

Memo appended to application stating time for filing might be excluded as District Magistrate moved Advocate-General to file appeal under s.417 CrPC, but State declined and intimation received on April 1, 1960.
Division Bench of Punjab High Court passed order 'Admitted' on September 1, 1960.
At hearing before Falshaw and Grover, JJ., preliminary objection raised by respondent that appeal out of time.
Appellant admitted appeal filed after period in s.417(4) CrPC but argued delay condonable under s.5 Limitation Act and condoned when admitted.
High Court held no application made for extension, did not condone delay on admission, s.417(4) is special law under s.29(2) Limitation Act, s.5 not available, dismissed appeal as barred by time.
Appellant obtained certificate of fitness from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of s.5 of Limitation Act 1908 apply to application for special leave to appeal from order of acquittal under sub-s.(3) of s.417 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay in filing application for special leave condonable under s.5 Limitation Act; delay condoned by Bench when appeal admitted.

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal out of time under s.417(4) CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: s.417 CrPC recast by Act XXVI 1955 introduced special provision for private complainant appeal from acquittal with 60-day limit in s.417(4), unlike State appeals under Art.157 Limitation Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intended to curtail litigation duration post-acquittal and limit private appeals strictly to 60 days.

court_reasoning.text: s.417(4) is special law of limitation within meaning of s.29(2) Limitation Act as it prescribes different period from general law; s.5 not applicable per s.29(2)(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Code is general procedural law but contains special time bars for particular cases like s.417(3)(4).

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished views of Allahabad Full Bench, Andhra, Madras High Courts; approved earlier Allahabad, Bombay Full Bench, and Punjab High Court views.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bombay Full Bench in Anjanabai v. Yeshwantrao correctly held s.417(4) special law.

holdings.text: s.5 Limitation Act does not apply to application for special leave under s.417(3) CrPC; s.417(4) is special law excluding s.5.

precedents_cited.relevance: Allahabad DB held s.417(4) bars extension, s.5 not apply.
Allahabad FB overruled prior view, held Code not special law, s.5 applies.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. V. Subbareddi v. D. Papireddi

precedents_cited.relevance: Madras held s.5 applies as no difference in periods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Coimbatore Municipality v. K. L. Narayanan
precedents_cited.relevance: Madras held s.5 available to private prosecutor.
Bombay FB held s.417(4) special law under s.29(2) Limitation Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. M. Thakur v. The State of Bihar
Canara Bank Ltd. v. The Warden Insurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Example of special limitation in Bombay Land Requisition Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs appeals from acquittal; s.417(4) imposes 60-day bar for special leave by complainant, held special law.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: s.5 for condonation excluded by s.29(2) for special laws like s.417(4); Art.157 for State appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges against respondent for deceitful marriage/ intercourse.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Punjab High Court, holding s.5 Limitation Act inapplicable to application under s.417(3) CrPC due to s.417(4) being special law; appeal from acquittal order barred by time.

key_quotes.text: the bar of time prescribed by sub-s.(4) of s.417 was a special law within the meaning of s.29(2) of the Limitation Act, and that, therefore, s.5 of the Limitation Act would not be available
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability of s.5.

key_quotes.text: the view taken by the High Court of Punjab is entirely correct.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final affirmation upholding High Court dismissal.

key_quotes.text: No application under sub-section (3) for the grant of special leave to appeal from the order of acquittal shall be entertained by the High Court after the expiry of sixty days
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes mandatory language of s.417(4) CrPC.
